Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The stonesignal package provides a server-based application to record location data sent from devices.
This section of the documentation describes the internal stonesignal model.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: A device is a piece of GPS (or other location technology) enabled electronic equipment. In the typical use case, a device will be a smartphone.

Subsection.title: ID
Subsection.Paragraph: Devices are assigned device IDs. A device ID is a public UUID value that identifies the device.

Subsection.title: Key
Subsection.Paragraph: Devices are assigned device keys. A device key is a secret 32-byte random value that the device uses to authenticate itself to the device API.

The text encoding for a device key is given by the pattern [A-F0-9]{64}. So, for example, the string 02210D83680AC0F4A50C47F51DCCE35610DE59717623A0D9408067279A63D511 is a well-formed device key, whilst 02210d83680ac0f4a50c47f51dcce35610de59717623a0d9408067279a63d511 is not.

Subsection.title: Device API
Subsection.Paragraph: The device API is the interface exposed to devices. The device API serves only one purpose: It accepts location updates from devices and records them into the database.

Subsection.title: Admin API
Subsection.Paragraph: The admin API is the interface exposed to administrators.

Subsection.title: Data API
Subsection.Paragraph: The data API is the interface exposed to data analysis applications.

Subsection.title: Audit Log
Subsection.Paragraph: The server maintains an append-only audit log consisting of a series of audit events. An audit event has an integer id, an owner (represented by an account UUID), a timestamp, a type, and a message consisting of a set of key/value pairs.
Each operation that changes the underlying database typically results in an event being logged to the audit log.
